title: P83-1004

sentences.text: Metagrammatical formalisms that combine context-free phrase structure rules and metarules -LRB- MPS grammars -RRB- allow concise statement of generalizations about the syntax of natural languages .
Unconstrained MPS grammars , unfortunately , are not computationally safe .
We evaluate several proposals for constraining them , basing our assessment on computational tractability and explanatory adequacy .
We show that none of them satisfies both criteria , and suggest new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms .

Entity-unconstrained_mp_grammar.label: Unconstrained MPS grammars
Entity-unconstrained_mp_grammar.description: Unconstrained MPS grammars are a type of metagrammatical formalism that combines context-free phrase structure rules and metarules, but they lack computational safety.

Entity-metarule.label: metarules
Entity-metarule.description: Metarules are linguistic rules that facilitate the formulation of generalizations about the syntax of natural languages within metagrammatical formalisms, specifically in the context of MPS grammars that integrate context-free phrase structure rules.

Entity-mp_grammar.label: MPS grammars
Entity-mp_grammar.description: MPS grammars are a type of linguistic model that integrate context-free phrase structure rules with metarules to facilitate the expression of generalizations regarding the syntax of natural languages.

Entity-metagrammatical_formalism.label: Metagrammatical formalisms
Entity-metagrammatical_formalism.description: Metagrammatical formalisms are theoretical frameworks that integrate context-free phrase structure rules with metarules, enabling the concise expression of generalizations regarding the syntax of natural languages.

Entity-computationally_safe.label: computationally safe
Entity-computationally_safe.description: The term 'computationally safe' refers to a property of metagrammatical formalisms, specifically indicating that certain grammatical frameworks, such as unconstrained MPS grammars, do not guarantee computational tractability and may lead to inefficiencies or ambiguities in processing natural language syntax.

Entity-generalization_about_the_syntax_o.label: generalizations about the syntax of natural languages
aliases: generalizations about the syntax of natural languages
Entity-generalization_about_the_syntax_o.description: Generalizations about the syntax of natural languages refer to the concise statements and rules that describe the structural patterns and principles governing the formation of sentences in various natural languages, as facilitated by metagrammatical formalisms like MPS grammars.

mentions.local_name: generalizations about the syntax of natural languages

Entity-proposal.label: proposals
Entity-proposal.description: The term 'proposals' refers to various suggestions and recommendations aimed at constraining unconstrained metagrammatical formalisms, specifically MPS grammars, in order to enhance their computational tractability and explanatory adequacy.

Entity-several_proposal.label: several proposals
Entity-several_proposal.description: Several proposals refer to various suggested methods or approaches aimed at constraining unconstrained metagrammatical formalisms, specifically MPS grammars, in order to enhance their computational safety and explanatory adequacy.

Entity-context-free_phrase_structure_rul.label: context-free phrase structure rules
Entity-context-free_phrase_structure_rul.description: Context-free phrase structure rules are formal rules used in linguistics to define the syntactic structure of sentences by specifying how symbols can be replaced with combinations of other symbols in a hierarchical manner.

Entity-both_criterion.label: both criteria
Entity-both_criterion.description: The term 'both criteria' refers to the dual requirements of computational tractability and explanatory adequacy that are used to evaluate proposals for constraining metagrammatical formalisms in the context of MPS grammars.

Entity-none_of_them.label: none of them
Entity-none_of_them.description: The term 'none of them' refers to the various proposals evaluated for constraining unconstrained metagrammatical formalisms, specifically MPS grammars, which fail to meet the criteria of computational tractability and explanatory adequacy.

Entity-new_direction_for_research.label: new directions for research
Entity-new_direction_for_research.description: New directions for research refers to proposed avenues of investigation aimed at exploring alternative metagrammatical formalisms that address the limitations of current MPS grammars in terms of computational safety and explanatory adequacy.

Entity-natural_language.label: natural languages
Entity-natural_language.description: Natural languages are complex systems of communication that consist of structured sets of symbols and rules used by humans for verbal and written expression.

Entity-syntax_of_natural_language.label: syntax of natural languages
Entity-syntax_of_natural_language.description: The syntax of natural languages refers to the set of rules and principles that govern the structure and formation of sentences in human languages.

Entity-syntax.label: syntax
Entity-syntax.description: Syntax refers to the set of rules, principles, and processes that govern the structure of sentences in a given language, determining how words and phrases are arranged to convey meaning.

Entity-computational_tractability.label: computational tractability
Entity-computational_tractability.description: Computational tractability refers to the feasibility of solving a computational problem within a reasonable amount of time and resources, often assessed in terms of algorithmic efficiency and resource requirements.

Entity-explanatory_adequacy.label: explanatory adequacy
Entity-explanatory_adequacy.description: Explanatory adequacy is a criterion used to assess the extent to which a theoretical framework or model can adequately explain the phenomena it addresses.

Entity-criterion.label: criteria
Entity-criterion.description: Criteria are standards or principles used to evaluate or measure the quality, performance, or suitability of something.

Entity-research.label: research
Entity-research.description: Research refers to a systematic investigation or academic activity aimed at discovering, interpreting, or revising facts, theories, or applications in a particular field of study.

summary: Metagrammatical formalisms that combine context-free phrase structure rules and metarules -LRB- MPS grammars -RRB- allow concise statement of generalizations about the syntax of natural languages . Unconstrained MPS grammars , unfortunately , are not computationally safe . We evaluate several proposals for constraining them , basing our assessment on computational tractability and explanatory adequacy . We show that none of them satisfies both criteria , and suggest new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms .

Predicate-combine.label: combine
Predicate-combine.description: The predicate 'combine' indicates a process or action in which two or more elements, represented by the subject and object, are brought together to form a unified whole. This can involve the integration of different concepts, structures, or systems, resulting in a new entity that incorporates characteristics or functionalities from each of the original components.

Predicate-allow.label: allow
Predicate-allow.description: The predicate 'allow' indicates a permissive relationship where the subject provides the opportunity or capacity for the object to occur, be realized, or be considered. It suggests that the subject enables or facilitates the existence or acceptance of the object, often implying a sense of freedom or possibility in relation to the object.

Predicate-about.label: about
Predicate-about.description: The predicate 'about' serves to indicate the subject's focus or the topic of discussion, connecting it to the object that represents the specific area, concept, or phenomenon being addressed. It establishes a relationship where the subject provides information, insights, or commentary regarding the object, thereby framing the object as the central theme or matter of interest in the context of the subject.

Predicate-are_not.label: are not
Predicate-are_not.description: The predicate 'are not' serves to establish a negation or denial relationship between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject does not possess the quality, characteristic, or state described by the object. In this context, it implies that the subject is distinctly different from or lacks the attributes associated with the object, thereby clarifying the limitations or exclusions relevant to the subject.

Predicate-evaluate.label: evaluate
Predicate-evaluate.description: The predicate 'evaluate' signifies the action of assessing or appraising the quality, value, or significance of the object by the subject. In this context, the subject undertakes a process of examination or judgment regarding the object, which is typically a set of items, ideas, or proposals, to determine their merits or suitability.

Predicate-satisfies.label: satisfies
Predicate-satisfies.description: The predicate 'satisfies' indicates that the subject meets the requirements or conditions specified by the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject fulfills or complies with the criteria or standards represented by the object.

Predicate-constrain.label: constrain
Predicate-constrain.description: The predicate 'constrain' indicates a relationship where the subject imposes limitations or restrictions on the object, thereby influencing its characteristics, behavior, or possibilities. This relationship suggests that the subject has the capacity to define boundaries or conditions that the object must adhere to, resulting in a more controlled or defined state of the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or subset that falls under the wider category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a broader scope or concept that includes the subject within its definition.
